awd_titl_txt: Rapid testosterone signaling receptor TRPM8 regulates sexual reward and satiety
awd_abstract_narration:
Testosterone is an essential steroid hormone that regulates the development of the male reproductive system and dimorphic reproductive behaviors in all vertebrates. Testosterone stimulates protein synthesis by regulating the expression of genes; a time-dependent process that is completed within hours. Testosterone also exerts rapid actions that take place within minutes. Rapid signaling induced by testosterone affects numerous behavioral traits in animals, including reproductive behavior, aggression, and fear. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying rapid testosterone actions are poorly understood. A recent discovery identified a novel testosterone receptor that resides on the cell surface and is responsible for rapid testosterone actions. This project is designed to investigate the intricate details of this rapid testosterone signaling mechanism and reveal its role in reproductive and social behaviors in rodents. Specifically, this project will assess how rapid signaling through the novel testosterone receptor regulates steroid synthesis, sexually dimorphic behaviors, and rewarding aspects of these behaviors. This project also offers a broader impact on society and aims to enhance educational basis in understanding organismal differences during development. It includes scientific training of students at the post-graduate, graduate, and undergraduate levels, and development of educational program among four participating universities. 


It is well known that genomic steroid receptors regulate behaviors indirectly via their downstream molecular targets. A recent study revealed that the Transient Receptor Potential ion channel of the Melastatin group, TRPM8, serves as a direct ionotropic testosterone receptor. Application of picomolar testosterone concentrations elicited TRPM8 channel openings and evoked calcium influx in the cells. This finding ignited an interest in whether TRPM8 directly regulates dimorphic behaviors. The mechanism of this conceptually novel physiological role of TRPM8 in mediating testosterone-dependent behaviors and sex dimorphism is the main objective of this project. This application will use a combination of techniques, including biochemical and biophysical analysis, imaging, electrophysiology, molecular biology, fluorescent spectroscopy, and animal behavioral studies. Three specific aims will: (a) determine the mechanism of TRPM8-exerted control of steroidogenesis, (b) assess the mechanism of testosterone-TRPM8 pathway in reward; and (c) reflect on the role of TRPM8 in brain development. The study will open new avenues for understanding the role of TRPM8 in testosterone-driven behaviors and sex differences. The research and educational programs will be developed through post-graduate, graduate, and undergraduate training among four collaborative universities. The results will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Testosterone has previously been observed to be a high affinity agonist for a nonselective Ca2+ channel, transient receptor potential melastatin-8 (TRPM8). Our present research investigates the potential influence truncated TRPM8 channel expression may have on gene expression, motivation and behavior by conducting a comprehensive analysis using a variety of different tests. Our analysis included an assessment of steroid hormone levels (cortisol, estrogen, and testosterone), RNA sequencing analysis, and an array of behavioral experiments relevant to dopamine function.

            There were significant differences in steroid hormone levels among mice with truncated TRPM8 (TRPM8-/-) compared to wild-type control (TRPM8+/+). Cortisol levels were significantly decreased in both male and female TRPM8-/- compared to the control group. Estradiol levels indicated a tendency toward decreased levels in male TRPM8-/-, while female TRPM8-/- mice showed a trend toward increased levels. Notably, among both male and female TRPM8-/-, testosterone levels were increased compared to TRPM8+/+. These changes in steroid levels correspond with our previously reported findings of altered behavior in the same group of mice (Mohandas et al., 2015).

            To further understand the function of the TRPM8 channel, we analyzed RNA sequencing data from specific brain regions where TRPM8 is more abundant: the olfactory bulb, amygdala, hypothalamus, and insula cortex. These regions are implicated in regulating sexual behavior and reward pathways in mice. The results indicated differential expression in ten signaling pathways, providing insights into additional mechanisms modified in these mice and potential targets for future research.

            One of the behavioral experiments conducted was the light/dark box, an assessment of exploratory and anxiety-like behaviors. Aged male TRPM8-/- mice showed reduced exploratory behavior with significantly less time spent in the white area compared to aged male TRPM8+/+; conversely, young TRPM8-/- mice showed increased exploratory behavior compared to TRPM8+/+. There was no difference in behavior between female TRPM8-/- and TRPM8+/+. These results suggest a possible interplay between age, sex, and TRPM8 channel activity in the expression of these behaviors. It is possible that truncated TRPM8 activity is affected with age in the development of anxiety-like behaviors with male mice being more susceptible to these effects than females.

            These findings demonstrate that the TRPM8 channel likely influences steroid regulation in both male and female mice and affects other signaling pathways. Notably, the impaired TRPM8 channel in conjunction with age seems to result in abnormal anxiety-like behaviors in male mice but not in female mice, indicating a potential sexual dimorphism in dopamine-sensitive behaviors. Further research is needed to fully understand the specific role of the TRPM8 channel in behavior, especially in the contexts of aging and sexual dimorphism.
